Topics: Reading Information - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:“Sometimes people call ours a 'throwaway society.' ”
What evidence does the author provide to support this point?

A.Choice: People get rid of stuff easily.

Key.Rationale: The author provides multiple examples of ways in which we use things and then throw them away.
This choice does not relate to how the author supports the given point.

C.Choice: People like to get things shipped.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not relate to how the author supports the given point.

D.Choice: People outgrow toys after a while.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not relate to how the author supports the given point.

SubTopics: Explain events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text, including what happened and why, based on specific information in the text.
Content: According to the section titled “Recycle It!,” what happens after goods are recycled?

Key.Rationale: This choice is not correct since it describes actions that occur before goods are recycled.

B.Choice: They are set out on the curb.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not correct since it describes an action that occur before goods are recycled.
This choice is not correct since it describes an action that occur before goods are recycled.

D.Choice: They are turned into new things.

Key.Rationale: This choice describes a process that happens after goods are recycled.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 4 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:“Experience the outdoors in all sorts of weather — from a sunny day at the beach or lake to a wintry adventure when it snows.”
Which meaning of the word experience is used in the sentence?

Key.Rationale: This choice is not correct since it does not mean the same thing as “experience” in the context of the sentence.
This choice is not correct since it does not mean the same thing as “experience” in the context of the sentence.
This choice is not correct since it does not mean the same thing as “experience” in the context of the sentence.
“Take one” is the meaning of “experience” as it is used in the sentence.

Content: Which word from the sentence best supports the answer in Part One? Choose one answer.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not correct since it does not support the meaning of “experience” in the context of the sentence.
Te word “adventure” supports the concept of “taking on” something.
This choice is not correct since it does not support the meaning of “experience” in the context of the sentence.
This choice is not correct since it does not support the meaning of “experience” in the context of the sentence.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:“But before you travel the globe, take a look at your own backyard.”
What does the phrase “travel the globe” mean as used in the sentence?

Key.Rationale: This choice does not make sense based on the context of the passage.

B.Choice: get in a car for a trip

Key.Rationale: This choice does not make sense based on the context of the passage.
This choice does not make sense based on the context of the passage.
“Travel” implies making a “journey” and “globe” suggests going “far from home.”

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 4 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:“Then you can watch with pride as your tree takes root and your garden plants grow from s͟p͟r͟i͟g͟s to big plants full of ripe, red tomatoes or tiny, succulent blueberries.”
What does the word s͟p͟r͟i͟g͟s mean as used in the sentence?

Key.Rationale: This choice is not the correct meaning of “sprigs” and does not relate to the sequence indicated by the words “from” and “to” in the sentence.
This choice is not the correct meaning of “sprigs” and does not relate to the sequence indicated by the words “from” and “to” in the sentence.
Tthe words “garden plants grow sprigs from” suggests to the reader that the plants are growing over time.
This choice is not the correct meaning of “sprigs” and does not relate to the sequence indicated by the words “from” and “to” in the sentence.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which sentence from the passage is an example of a way to reuse something?

A.Choice: “They do need to be disposed of properly, though, so make sure your mom or dad helps if one breaks.”

Key.Rationale: This choice relates to throwing something away.

B.Choice: “Unplug the chargers for your phone and MP3 player when you're not using them.”

Key.Rationale: This choice relates to saving energy.

C.Choice: “Take paper from your computer printouts and use the other side for more computer printing or just to draw or doodle on.”

Key.Rationale: Using the other side of computer paper is an example of reusing something.

D.Choice: “By separating plastic bottles, cans, glass bottles, and more, you're reducing the amount of trash that goes to the landfill.”

Key.Rationale: This choice relates to reducing the amount of trash going into landfills.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
What point does the author make about being outdoors?

A.Choice: It requires many hours of hard work.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not supported by information in the passage.

B.Choice: It can be enjoyed by anyone.

Key.Rationale: The passage says that Earth is a “huge and glorious place that's ready for you to explore.”

C.Choice: It should be avoided due to problems.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not supported by information in the passage.

D.Choice: It can be organized among friends.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not supported by information in the passage.

Content: Which sentences from the passage support the answer in Part One? Choose two answers.

A.Choice: “It also means taking special steps to protect the environment — the water, the land, and the air we breathe.”

Key.Rationale: This choice defines what being green is.

B.Choice: “When you use less of something, you do a good thing for the Earth.”

Key.Rationale: This choice focuses on using fewer resources.

C.Choice: “Go for a hike, visit local nature centers and gardens, climb up mountains, and explore lazy creeks.”

Key.Rationale: This choice gives an example of activities that people can do outside.

D.Choice: “If so, get out there and get your hands dirty.”

Key.Rationale: This choice gives an example of activities that people can do outside.

Topics: Reading Information - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Interpret text features (e.g., headings, graphics, charts, timelines, diagrams) and/or make connections between text and the content of text features.
Content: What information do the headings help the reader understand?

A.Choice: the system to categorize what people buy

Key.Rationale: The headings do not relate to buying anything.

B.Choice: the ways to be green and help the planet

Key.Rationale: The headings describe different ways to help the Earth.

C.Choice: the steps to take to protect plants on Earth

Key.Rationale: The headings are not steps and relate to more than just protecting plants

D.Choice: the order in which we should protect Earth

Key.Rationale: The headings do not reflect a specific order of how to protect the Earth.

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Which sentence from the passage best states the main idea?

A.Choice: “Plants are green, and without them the Earth wouldn't be such a lovely home for us human beings.”

Key.Rationale: This choice merely states a fact and does not relate to actions people can take to help the environment.

B.Choice: “Every day, people make choices that affect the amount of trash and pollution that gets produced in our world.”

Key.Rationale: The passage is mainly about how people can reduce, reuse, and recycle items to positively impact the amount of trash and pollution produced.

C.Choice: “Enjoy the Earth — walk in the woods, plant a tree, and eat some of the delicious food it produces.”

Key.Rationale: This choice reflects one part of being green but not the main idea of the entire passage.

D.Choice: “When you can, walk or ride your bike instead of driving in the car.”

Key.Rationale: This choice is only a detail related to how to reduce energy use.

SubTopics: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Content: The decision of Lyle's family to move away has an effect on the main characters in the passage. Write an essay analyzing how this decision affects Lyle and Amanda. Use evidence from the passage to support your response.

SubTopics: Correctly use frequently confused words (e.g., to, too, two; there, their, they're).
Content: Which underlined word is used correctly?

A.Choice: Did you get the e-mail I s͟c͟e͟n͟t you?

Key.Rationale: The word should be “sent.”

B.Choice: Will you w͟e͟i͟g͟h͟t for me at the park?

Key.Rationale: The word should be “wait.”

C.Choice: I will bring s͟u͟m snacks for us to eat.

Key.Rationale: The word should be “some.”

D.Choice: Please do not r͟a͟i͟s͟e the shade.

Key.Rationale: This choice is the only word that is used correctly based on the context of the sentence.

SubTopics: Choose words and phrases for effect.
Content: Read the paragraph from a story.

:box:(1) It was cleanup day at the school, and John was assigned to clean out a closet in the library. (2) While he was moving an old bookcase, he discovered a stack of newspapers that __________. (3) Carefully, he picked up one newspaper and wiped the dust from it. (4) He was able to read the front page: “Man Walks on the Moon!”
Choose the most descriptive group of words to complete sentence 2.

A.Choice: had a great amount of dust on them

Key.Rationale: This choice is less descriptive than the best option and does not use visual language.

B.Choice: looked so dusty they could not be read

Key.Rationale: This choice is less descriptive than the best option and does not use visual language.

C.Choice: were resting beneath a thick coat of powdery dust

Key.Rationale: “Resting beneath a thick coating of powdery dust” is the most descriptive choice and uses language that provokes imagery.

D.Choice: looked like they had been dusty for a very long time

Key.Rationale: This choice is less descriptive than the best option and does not use visual language.

Content: Read the sentences from a story.

:box:(1) My grandmother asked me to water the tomato plants. (2) I filled the watering can. (3) Then I began to pour water on the plants. (4) A toad jumped down and landed on my shoe. (5) That was sure a surprise.
Which sentence should most likely end with an exclamation point to show excitement?

Key.Rationale: This choice merely indicates action and does not express a strong emotion.
This choice merely indicates action and does not express a strong emotion.
This choice merely indicates action and does not express a strong emotion.
The word “surprise” indicates the use of an exclamation point to express emotion.

SubTopics: Use a comma before a coordinating conjunction in a compound sentence.
Content: Read the paragraph.

:box:(1) Brian's sisters went to the library but Brian stayed home. (2) He had a cold and was tired. (3) He decided to play checkers or chess with his older brother instead. (4) Checkers and chess were Brian's favorite games.
Which revision should be made to the paragraph to correctly punctuate a compound sentence?

A.Choice: Add a comma after l͟i͟b͟r͟a͟r͟y in sentence 1.

Key.Rationale: A comma is needed before the coordinating conjunction that separates two independent clauses.

B.Choice: Add a comma after c͟o͟l͟d in sentence 2.

Key.Rationale: The conjunction does not join two independent clauses.

C.Choice: Add a comma after c͟h͟e͟c͟k͟e͟r͟s in sentence 3.

Key.Rationale: The conjunction does not join two independent clauses.

D.Choice: Add a comma after c͟h͟e͟s͟s in sentence 4.

Key.Rationale: The conjunction is used to create a compound subject, not to separate two independent clauses.
